We are being told that the instantaneous rate of change of the function is at least of 3 on the interval [-1,2], so the smallest possible value of \(f\)(2) is the case where the function has the smallest rate of change, that is a constant rate of change of 3 which means it is a straight line (of slope 3).

And since we are starting at the point (-1,9) with a slope of 3 and a run of 3 (from -1 to 2) we will end up with a rise of 9 and so the minimal value of \(f\)(2) is 18.

Alternatively, you can use the MVT (Mean Value Theorem), which states that if f(x) is defined and continuous on the interval [a,b] and differentiable on (a,b), then there is at least one number c in the interval (a,b) (that is a < c < b) such that

\(f'(c) = \frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}\)

If we assume \(f(x)\) is differentiable on (-1,2) and differentiable and continuous on the interval [-1,2], we can use the MVT which gives:

\(\frac{f(2)-f(-1)}{2-(-1)} = f'(c)\)

For some value c in the interval (-1,2). However, we know that \(f'(x) \geq 3\) for any value between -1 and 2, thus, \(f'(c) \geq 3\). Adding this, plugging in known values, and simplifying gives:

\(\frac{f(2) - 9}{3} \geq 3\)

Solving for f(2) we get \(f(2) \geq 18\), thus the minimal value of f(2) is 18.
